Patch Set 13:

(6 comments)

Patch Set 13:

(5 comments)

How does this play with webui-vue? 
webui-vue uses Axios which doesn't appear to have HTTP/2 support. 

https://github.com/axios/axios/issues/1175

> How does this play with webui-vue? 

I'd be surprised if anything were broken.  The http 1.1 paths are still present and functional (given we're required to have them for Redfish compliance).

> webui-vue uses Axios which doesn't appear to have HTTP/2 support. 
> 
> https://github.com/axios/axios/issues/1175

Not sure what to do about that, but it looks like someone has a transport adapter to do http/2.  FWIW, I'm not sure if we'd see a significant improvement in webui performance with this, given everything is happening at human speed.  This patch is mainly targetting stuff that polls the bmc quite often during monitoring tasks.

signed off before the WIP is removed. Also, please explain why this is needed, why this 53.4KB is worth adding. Also, a couple sentences on HTTP/2 differences.


Part some examples of what I might expect:

"HTTP/2 changes do not require any changes to how existing web applications work, but new applications can take advantage of new features for increased speed. HTTP/2 leaves all of HTTP/1.1's high-level semantics, such as methods, status codes, header fields, and URIs, the same. What is new in HTTP/2 is how the data is framed and transported between the client and the server." <Took from Wikipedia: >

....

bmcweb will only support HTTP/2 over TLS...

...

HTTP/2 should allow for improvements in the speed of..
Improvements seen in speed at ... when :

...
Redfish is adding support for HTTP/2, see issue 5260

...

> signed off before the WIP is removed. Also, please explain why this is needed, why this 53.4KB is worth adding. Also, a couple sentences on HTTP/2 differences.
> 
> 
> Part some examples of what I might expect:
> 
> "HTTP/2 changes do not require any changes to how existing web applications work, but new applications can take advantage of new features for increased speed. HTTP/2 leaves all of HTTP/1.1's high-level semantics, such as methods, status codes, header fields, and URIs, the same. What is new in HTTP/2 is how the data is framed and transported between the client and the server." <Took from Wikipedia: >
> 

ACK, totally reasonable.  This patch is still in the "Is this possible and reasonable" phase.

> ....
> 
> bmcweb will only support HTTP/2 over TLS...
> 
> ...
> 
> HTTP/2 should allow for improvements in the speed of..
> Improvements seen in speed at ... when :

ACK.

> 
> ...
> Redfish is adding support for HTTP/2, see issue 5260

Can't link internal-only Redfish discussions in public according to our rules.  (Although we should revisit that rule, because I think it hurts more than it helps).

> 
> ...
A big TESTing statement. ;)
Cool stuff!
In the commit msg can you explain why this should be enabled by default?

ACK.  Short version, because we enable all generic, non-experimental, non-oem features by default;  It's up to users to disable things if they choose to, but once http/2 is in the Redfish standard, I can't think of a reason anyone would want to disable it, except maybe binary size, but even that is marginal in difference.
I though it was always styled "HTTP/2". Can you add another sentence here about HTTP/2, maybe mentioned we use nghttp2
ACK
